comments.commentBody: I have made numerous suggestions.  You just haven't been paying attention.  I promise to resubmit them in future posts.

You don't need to make it about race in order to recognize that people with guns get away with murder, and when cops do it, it's even worse because they put protecting their fellow cops above honest.

We need fewer guns, and better penalties for those who use them recklessly.

Ten shots? That's excessive by any sensible standard

@Lew

You are wrong like usual. Local and federal authorities can end the carnage. Curfews on the bars and strip clubs. Smash the gangs. Deport illegal aliens. Stiff sentences without parole. They choose not to.

Your solution? Disarm the law abiding citizens who want to defend their families and property.

Ten shots seems beyond extreme. I admire the parents for not immediately crying racism, instead waiting for more information. I can't imagine how hard it is for them to remain level headed in such an incredibly emotional situation. The sad truth is that it may have been racially motivated, or it may have been a case of an incompetent police officer who lost his head and panicked. Either way, our country seems to believe that having dedicated, well-trained and competent public safety personnel is a waste of time and money. As cities across the country demand that their debts be paid by the police officers and firefighters who serve them, we can expect to see less and less qualified people in these roles, and our public safety will deteriorate as a consequence.

@HDNY.

You are wrong as usual. The Liberals who govern our inner cities are responsible for the carnage by not cracking down on the gangs for fear of offending race hustlers Sharpton and Jackson. It is the Liberals and their desire for votes and power who have blood on their hands.

@Justin

I am not about to surrender the rights that were won by our forefathers 200+ years ago. Without those guns in private hands there would be no USA.

Being the highly tactical man he is, I'm sure that Field Marshall el-Sisi understands the risks associated with his nomination for president and probable success at being elected. But as a possible president he will be the commander-in-chief, and as such will be even more effective at fighting terrorism like the downing of the military helicopter in Sinai yesterday.

Even before announcing whether will run for president, the Egyptian people have already given el-Sisi a mandate to both run and get elected, as well as clean up the country of any remnant elements of terrorism. When the answer to terrorism is swift then any enemy of the state, jihadi terrorist or not, will think twice before attacking. The families of all the fallen soldiers, police, and pilots have obtained his promise to bring swift retribution to these who killed their sons.
Wish your dream come true.

You are right, one would think given the turmoil and bad economic state of Egypt, this would be one of the world's least sought after jobs. Let's hope he knows what he is doing, and doing so for the right reasons.

While planning to hang up army boots and forcing feet to fit into larger sized civilian shoes Genetral Abdul Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt should not only reckon with an ordinary fact that such over trying could often result into getting one's limb fractured, or having to confront a forced barefoot run from presidential palace to prison, as happened with his Arab awakening hit General predecessor Hosni Mubarak. Again, oblivious though of history, still General Sisi would do well to remember the elementary lesson of history: those who ignore history are often condemned to suffer its replay, specially its tragic aspects. The shooting down of state aircraft the other day allegedly by militants provides a small clue to the future events, Sisi would do well to remember.

Someone who hasn't been on the outside looking in, someone who hasn't been looked at as if suspicion is what they deserve as a matter of course, someone who hasn't woke in the morning and go9ne to sleep at night as the Outsider, the Other, the Second Class Citizen, cannot understand the agony of these kinds of injustices. I hear you Mr. Knox.

I think Mr. Sailer tried to knock down your outrage because you live in a lily-white and privileged enclave.

What Mr. Sailer fails to realize is, even if someone can't imagine what it is like to directly experience these kinds of outrages, human empathy allows us to be party to each others pain. Across all kinds of distances and differences, we can feel it. Only a cynic would think otherwise.

The internet is nothing more than a series of tubes filled with pornography and cats.

I'll let you figure out which category Mr. Moves site falls in to.

Once again, to those who think cops are "heroes," let this be a reminder. There is NOTHING heroic about responding with overwhelming shock and awe when your opponent is unarmed and over-matched, blindly staggering toward you in the glare of your headlights, asking for help. This take-no-risks-so-that-I-can-make-sure-I-live-to-retirement-at-45 has GOT TO STOP. Disarm the cops NOW. Put them out there with night sticks, like cops in London. They can use their radios and their smarts, and be members of the communities they live in, rather than hatchet men. Let one commanding officer in each company have a gun, and make the rest of those cowards and bullies with hyperactive trigger fingers comport themselves like respectful public servants, damnit. I'm absolutley sick of cops acting like animals. It's a job that attracts bullies in the first place. We should neuter that tendency by divesting them of the power to kill, maim or hurt. After all, they are there for our protection, not to abuse us.

The fact that they handcuffed Ferrell's corpse after shooting him ten times makes me want to throw up.

As a resident of the subdivision this occurred in I am left with many questions that the media can't provide any answers to. Have any of you listened to the 911 recording? I understand the woman was afraid. If I were home alone and someone was pounding on my door it would scare me too! However, her house alarm was so loud there was no way the dispatcher could hear what the "suspect" was yelling. Pleading for help after wrecking his car maybe? What injuries did he sustain? I've heard many cases of accidents causing an adrenaline rush. Did he have a concussion or other head trauma that may have confused him? We're just learning how much a concussion really affects one's brain! Maybe with his adrenaline amped up he didn't feel the taser? An injury that affected his hearing? I'm sure he too was scared after trying to get help and having a home alarm set off. I could go on with questions I hope to get answers to but it all comes down to the hope our judicial system will hear all the facts and justice will prevail. To those of you attempting to turn this tragedy into a racial case, you are a great part of the ignorance that affects this country!

The presentation of this case to the first grand jury suggests incompetence on the part of the AG's office. Apparently, some sort of abridged procedure was used so that only 14 grand jurors were required. Moreover, minimal evidence was presented to the grand jury, with only 2 witnesses testifying.

It seems apparent beyond all question that this is an extremely sensitive case, involving, as it does, a white officer shooting a black football star deep in the suburbs of North Carolina. Any AG with any sense would know that, in a case like this, you dot all your i"s and cross all your t's, and you certainly don't go before the grand jury making a half-hearted effort to indict. Lawyers are known to say that a prosecutor can indict a ham sandwich in the grand jury. If the AG has his charges rejected in a case like this, it sure suggests incompetence.

Instead of contemplating a run for governor, Mr. Cooper should step aside as AG and find a job where he causes less harm to the people of his state.

@Lew,

Not lashing out. I was just asking a question. I am sure many other people were wondering, too.

Wow, JK.  What an epiphany.  You suddenly realized, without anything to base it upon besides your own mind, that the people you despise were even more contemptible than you thought, because clearly they must be motivated by the perverse thoughts you attribute to them.  Congratulations! You are an honorary graduate of the Steve Bolger school of character, ethics and alternate reality of one's own mind.
The gangs have no trouble getting heroin. What makes you think they will have trouble getting guns?

Steve Bolger,

As much as you like to claim otherwise, with, of course, no facts, private concealed carry isn't about policing. It is about Defence. National carry laws are more about freedom of movement for private citizens. But. I am sure you will stick with your baseless accusations or outright lies. More your style and character.

Clairette Rose,

Why in the world would you think that I am not opposed to the stop and frisk policies of NYC? Or the hypocracy of its politicians who think they have some moral superiority offer the rest of the country to want to spread them around the country? But stopping a CCW permit holder to harrass him is, I think, a bit slower to being on topic.

Betty Van Lew,

So, because an injustice isn't the greatest injustice I. The world we should ignore it and just say, ho hum, it happens? This from the person who gets in a tizzy fit if some one dares to make public health coparisons or analogies on this forum. The hypocracy, or maybe just lack of insight, is startling.

I don't get it, Bru.

The hole in my Shoe-ish?
The Jew on the grass?

Lyrics by Rabbi Lane Hart?

There isn't anything to get Leapy other than the fact that Deb crowned SHOE's clue the clue of the day. The original clip I was going to share was a montage of SHOEs set to Traffic's 'Hole in My SHOE'. I decided on the less germane clip because the audio was sharper and of much higher quality than my first choice. I'll get the original posted later this afternoon and you'll see what I mean.

Here 'tis Leapy, my first pick.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xkZibZW9gDc

This one has more sole.

Here's a nice little slide SHOE for today's clip.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a77yHpjdUtU

I'm steadily coming to grips with this new comment box. It SCROLLS, but I liked my old comment box. Today, I'll take some comfort in being able to finger John's avatar. No new emu generated comments format is gonna stifle my enthusiasm.

With A LOT of love to ALLOT,

Bru

Steve,

You might note that the Gun Report more or less religiously calls every male 18 and over a 'man'. Laws in the U.S. tend to treat all those 18 and older as adults.

In any case if something is legal to own and legal to buy neither the seller nor anyone else has cause to ask the buyer 'why'.

I'm ready to go to bat with you to get universal background checks. And if the state (such as NY or NJ) want to ask why someone needs a concealed carry permit then talley ho. But turning shopping keepers into an inquisition, whether over guns or any other commodity just will not fly.

12 shots, 10 of which hit him? And what is the explanation of the fact that the shots entered his body and traveled downward, and that the family isn't allowed to see the video? I'm speechless. And people say America is the greatest country on earth.

"... we have more serious issues to deal with, and we should just stop harassing law-abiding gun owners."
That's about right.
Proposing that law enforcement officers not be armed is way out there.  Why not disarm the armed forces, too?
I would not bet on a narrowing Senate majority; also the GOP will lose ground in the House as well as state houses.  My prediction at least.

@Claire,

There is a difference between a fatality as a result of a crime and an accident. They have to be dealt with in different ways.

"it is not up to the NYT to pass judgement"

When does the NYT ever hesitate to pass judgement?

I thin that a Hayes type code should be brought back as for the depiction of guns in movies and tv. If the industry can get rid of cigarettes why not guns.

Hayes code excerpt:
4.The use of firearms;
5.Theft, robbery, safe-cracking, and dynamiting of trains, mines, buildings, etc. (having in mind the effect which a too-detailed description of these may have upon the moron);
6.Brutality and possible gruesomeness;
7.Technique of committing murder by whatever method;

#5 "moron" especially should be looked in regards to the modern definition of s someone "mentally unstable" not the older definition of someone "intellectually impaired"

I understand the desire and agree with the desire to separate shooting of people who were in the course of committing a crime, however, it is not up to the NYT to pass judgement before the courts.  I think the message, the impact, is that guns can wreak havoc when wielded both by innocents and malevolent.  Whether the solution is education, regulation, or arming everyone to the teeth (the "Cold War" option), I don't know.  But notice, people are dying in droves from gunshots.  That's what this blog does.  It calls attention to the fact that a horrific number of people, far more than the number of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, are dying every year in the streets of America.

So your State Insurance Commission loses its role? Going across state lines means no more than BC/BS having activities in multiple states with which insurance commission in charge.

Keep in mind that the anti PPACA act states refused to exert their insurance commission power to keep insurance offerings via federal website path inline. Responsible states used their insurance commission power to keep insurers charges in line; irresponsible, spiteful state legislators & governors like Fla, etc failed in their responsibilities utterly failed.

Right on - tax law that allows deduction of expenses for off shoring & deducting 100% of Corp. Overhead when only 20 revenue is taxed here. Bush lowered taxes for the most affluent while engaging in enough deficit spending to nearly double the national debt on his watch. GOP is certainly out to disenfranchise voters they believe are supportive of their opposition state by state in GOP states. Declined to expand medicaid and refused to use their insurance commission power to get better deals for their states' citizens. Etc.

Current republican voters in places like Kentucky are realizing their state implementation of PPACA & expanded Medicaid is really great - republican governors are being shamed into expanding medicaid after initial refusal.
